headline.main: Europe's Turn To Wrestle With Obesity

docs.lead_paragraph: Europe's food industry and consumer groups are to submit ideas to the European Union on Thursday on how to confront obesity, urging clear labeling of nutritional hazards and warning against aggressive marketing to children, but also allowing food producers to regulate themselves. Food companies, supermarket chains and consumer groups are expected to present their ideas on handling a health problem that, according to all involved, is becoming as serious in Europe as it is in the United States.
docs.snippet: Europe's food industry and consumer groups are to submit ideas to the European Union on how to confront obesity.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Thanksgiving rolls around, my thoughts turn to stuffing. I don't ordinarily stuff the birds I roast. But planning a turkey dinner for 20, I reflect on my options. I could make the stuffing with chestnuts, but I'd have to roast and peel them -- a tedious business. I could make it with dried fruit and bread crusts, but meat with fruit is a bore. I like cornbread in my stuffing, but it's a bother to bake and a risk to buy. I love the chicken liver and ricotta recipe, but Aunt Helen doesn't. What to do? My choice of stuffing at Thanksgiving influences my feelings about the holiday as a whole. Like other holidays, Thanksgiving is devoted to exceeding limits. We are supposed to get drunk on New Year's Eve and Purim; Christmas is required to be an orgy of generosity. But never do I receive such blanket permission for excess as I do from the spectacle of a plump turkey.
docs.snippet: On Thanksgiving you are invited to hurl aside moderation, restraint and the bad conscience with which you routinely approach the table.

docs.lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley Chief Executive Said to Be Looking at Hedge Fund Deal Five months into his term as chief executive of Morgan Stanley, John J. Mack is stepping up efforts to add businesses and possibly bolster his management team. Yesterday, Morgan Stanley severed ties with three former executives who were forced to leave the firm by Philip J. Purcell during his management shake-up earlier this year. While making such a break with executives whom some had hoped might return, Mr. Mack has stepped up his search to acquire a hedge fund. Within the last month, he offered to buy FrontPoint Partners, a hedge fund manager with more than $5 billion in assets, according to people who were briefed on the discussions. [Page C1.] Deadline Nears for Medicare Drug Decision The clock is ticking for millions of elderly and disabled people who must decide whether and when to enroll in one of the Medicare Part D drug plans that start Jan. 1. [C1.] Pinochet Is Arrested in Case Tied to Bank Accounts Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former military dictator of Chile, was arrested on tax fraud and passport forgery charges arising from secret bank accounts holding millions of dollars that he maintained under false names in the United States and elsewhere. [A8.] Congestion Eases on Day Before Thanksgiving The anxious rituals of Thanksgiving eve -- driving in bumper-to-bumper traffic, waiting for hours at the airport, boarding a train with no empty seats -- seemed to ease slightly this year, so much so that the day before Thanksgiving may be ceding its claim as the busiest travel day of the year. [A29.] The much-maligned Transportation Security Administration has been hiring industrial engineers and other efficiency experts to iron out the many kinks in its rapidly assembled operations. But that is little guarantee that wait times at airport checkpoints will shorten this Thanksgiving. [C3.] Former Broker Charged With Insider Trading Federal prosecutors have charged a former securities broker, David Pajcin, with insider trading related to information the authorities said he gleaned by illegally obtaining advance copies of BusinessWeek and buying stocks that the magazine was covering favorably. [C3.] Threat of Industrial Pollution in China The Chinese government's decision to cut potentially contaminated supplies of fresh water to the city of Harbin in the northeast has highlighted the threat that industrial pollution poses to public health and economic development across the nation. [A6.] In Germany, an Auto Parts Maker Thrives A relentless focus on costs has turned Continental, an auto parts maker, into a quiet star of German industry. While Delphi and its biggest customer, General Motors, are struggling to stave off financial ruin in the United States, Continental's profit is surging and its stock is hitting all-time highs. ''There's a cost burden that no one can manage away,'' Manfred Wennemer, above, the chief of Continental, said in an interview. ''The United States has to find a way to solve that.'' [C1.] U.S. Oil Companies Take Action Against Yemen Two United States oil companies, taking an uncommon tack, have filed arbitration proceedings against the government of Yemen for expropriating an oil-producing block with output of more than $1 billion a year. [C10.] Arcelor Makes Hostile Bid for Canadian Steelmaker In a bid to supply steel to North American auto plants, Luxembourg's Arcelor began a 4.3 billion Canadian dollar ($3.66 billion) hostile bid for Dofasco, a large Canadian steelmaker. [C10.] Europe to Seek Ways to Prevent Obesity Europe's food industry and consumer groups are to submit ideas to the European Union on how to confront obesity, urging clear labeling of nutritional hazards and warning against aggressive marketing to children, but also allowing food producers to regulate themselves. [C5.] Stocks Rise on Consumer Confidence Data Better-than-expected consumer confidence numbers and a drop in oil prices sent stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 44.66 points, to 10,916.09. The Standard & Poor's 500 added 4.38 points, to 1,265.61, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 6.42 points, to 2,259.98. [C10.] BlackBerry Maker Lowers Subscriber Forecast Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry phones and pagers, lowered its forecast for new subscribers as product releases are delayed and a lawsuit threatens to shut its service. [C16.] Son of Adelphia Founder Enters Guilty Plea Michael J. Rigas, a son of the founder of Adelphia Communications, pleaded guilty to a charge of making a false entry in a company record, eliminating the need for his retrial on much more serious charges. [C9.] Searching for CD Burners With Extra Sizzle As laptop sales continue to outpace desktop PC sales, manufacturers of aftermarket CD burners hope to see their products become more desirable alternatives to built-in burners. Circuits. [C7.]

docs.abstract: Nina Planck Op-Ed article opposes efforts by Organic Trade Association, which includes such giant food producers as Kraft, Dean Foods and General Mills, to dilute federal standards for organic foods; says consumers should look beyond organic label and seek out producers that exceed federal rules (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN I first sold my family's vegetables at farmers' markets in Virginia in 1980, Slow Food hadn't been born, and the phrase ''local foods'' was not yet in the lingo. The word ''organic,'' however, was in vogue, and our customers always asked the same question: Are you organic? Nine years old and barefoot, I tried not to appear flummoxed. I stumbled over answers, most of them beginning, ''No, but'' These replies failed to satisfy. People wanted to know in a phrase whether our food was clean and safe. I'm still grateful to the customer who said, ''Explain how you do farm.'' Soon our signs read ''No Pesticides'' or ''Our Chickens Run Free on Grass.''

headline.main: Mentor Leaves Options Open On Its Bid For Medicis

docs.lead_paragraph: The cosmetic medical device company Mentor indicated yesterday that it would not take Medicis Pharmaceutical's blunt rejection of its $2.2 unsolicited billion takeover proposal as the final word. In Mentor's view, the benefits of joining its breast implant and liposuction equipment businesses with Medicis's antiwrinkle drugs and prescription skin therapies are so clear that there is every reason to hope a deal will eventually be struck.
docs.snippet: The cosmetic medical device company Mentor indicated yesterday that it would not take Medicis Pharmaceutical's blunt rejection of its $2.2 unsolicited billion takeover proposal as the final word.
